node.title: gmsh with 1D lower dimensional elements into a 3D mesh
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
we have been trying to import a gmsh mesh consiting of 3D and 1D elements, but it does seem that the reading capability of the FileMeshGenerator in Moose does not support this type of combination (all is fine if the LD elements have a dim=dim_3d-1).
Attached the input *.geo file to reproduce the issue.
On a side node, we tried to play a bit around by merging and extracting block ids (below our Mesh block), but despite being able to generate the correct IDs for the 1D elements, while running a simulation with that geometry all internal connectivities are lost and the 1D elements does not have any influence on the overall behaviour.
Any help/hint would be highly appreciated.
Thanks,
Mauro
[Mesh]
  [add_inj]
    type = PolyLineMeshGenerator
    points = '2.5e3 5e3 -0.2e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -0.4e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -0.6e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -0.8e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -1.0e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -1.1e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -1.2e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -1.3e3
    2.5e3 5e3 -1.4e3'
    loop = false
  []
  [add_pro]
    type = PolyLineMeshGenerator
    points = '7.5e3 5e3 -0.2e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -0.4e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -0.6e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -0.8e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -1.0e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -1.1e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -1.2e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -1.3e3
    7.5e3 5e3 -1.4e3'
    loop = false
  []
  [input]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = 'mesh/fiel.msh'
  []
  [merge]
    type = MeshCollectionGenerator
    inputs = 'input add_inj add_pro'
  []
  [extract_inj]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = merge
    block_id = 1
    block_name = 'injector'
    top_right = '2.49e3 4.99e3 -0.19e3'
    bottom_left = '2.51e3 5.01e3 -1.41e3'
  []
  [extract_pro]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = extract_inj
    block_id = 2
    block_name = 'producer'
    top_right = '7.49e3 4.99e3 -0.19e3'
    bottom_left = '7.51e3 5.01e3 -1.41e3'
  []
[] 

fiel.zip

Hello
The MeshCollectionGenerator is explicit that it's not merging meshes, just appending. So the internal connectivities are indeed not working.
The StitchedMeshGenerator is the only one that merges them.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/StitchedMeshGenerator.html
However, I've never dealt with 3D & 1D elements in the same simulation in MOOSE. By lowerD we usually mean 2D for a 3D mesh. What physics are you going to use? Did you write your own kernels to deal with 1D?
Guillaume

Dear @GiudGiud,
thanks a lot for your reply. Indeed, I thought the same (about the MeshCollectionGenerator vs StichedMeshGenerator). However, to be able to stitch the meshes I would need to define a boundary and this breaks down for 3D and 1D (cannot find a common boundary to stitch them). I also see that lowerD means (max_dim-1), but ... We routinely run simulations (based on an in-house developed mesher) with 1D-2D-3D FEMs (there is an example on the gallery page). And, yes, we use our own developed kernel for the simulations.
This said, would you suggest us to write our own import routine?
Thanks

I think adding support for importing gmsh 1-2-3D mixed-dimensional meshes would be awesome.
@jwpeterson will know if it's needed or if there's something we can do right now.

Excellent! Let me know.
Mauro

@jwpeterson thanks! Almost right, if I added the lines as suggested I can retrieve the 1D elements though not exactly in the right manner
see below (the right way would be to have only the two vertical line elements). Will try to have a look deeper at that.

node.title: output the Extreme Value of material defined on surface
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I want to know how to get the the Extreme Value of material defined on surface by using postprocessor.
[AuxVariables]
  [./oxide_thickness]
    #order = CONSTANT
    #family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./oxide]
    type = MaterialRealAux
    property = oxide_thickness
    variable = oxide_thickness
    execute_on = 'initial linear'
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./oxide_thickness]
    type = OxidationMaterial
    boundary = side1
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./max_oxide_thickness1]
    type = ElementExtremeMaterialProperty
    mat_prop =  oxide_thickness
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [./max_oxide_thickness2]
    type = NodalExtremeValue
    variable = oxide_thickness
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

the material oxide_thickness  is defined on boundary side1 (the side1 is part of block1 ) and I want to obtain its maximum value.
When using the ElementExtremeMaterialProperty PP, it said that

oxide_thickness  was not defined on block1

While using NodalExtremeValue and setting the AuxVariables to First order Lagrangian, it shows:

Nodal AuxKernel 'oxide_thickness' attempted to reference material property 'property'
Consider using an elemental auxiliary variable for 'oxide_thickness'

Hello
There's no nodal material property, the "boundary" for the material property really refers to quadrature points on element sides on the boundary.
Can you try using a constant monomial and seeing if the code naturally only populates the DOFs near the side?
Otherwise there's several things we could try to add here, but will need some developing

SideExtremeMaterialProperty PP
some nodal projection to MaterialRealAux

Guillaume

the oxide_thickness is in the elements near the side:

the problem solved when I change into the following input:
[Materials]
  [./oxide_thickness]
    type = OxidationMaterial
    output_properties = 'oxide_thickness'   #added
    outputs = all     #added
    boundary = side1
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./max_oxide]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    variable = oxide_thickness
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

And the related [AuxVariables] and  [AuxKernels] were deleted.
Thanks for your help. @GiudGiud
sounds good. This is equivalent to MaterialRealAux + const monomial auxvariable, it just happens in the background due to matproperty output

Can I ask another question？
Except none  and all, what else can the outputs parameter be set in the Materials ?

any name of Outputs object in the [Outputs] block. For example, below final_exodus
[Outputs]
  [final_exodus]
     type = Exodus
     execute_on = FINAL
  []
[]
Thanks for your reply.
When the material object is included in Action, it seems the parameter output_properties and  outputs don't work. Will a SideExtremeMaterialProperty  PP be developed in MOOSE in the future?

You can still use the auxvariable/auxkernel route though.
We have no immediate plans on this object afaik. We d welcome the contribution though

node.title: malamute melt pool 3d example
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am in the process of setting up moose and malamute with the intent to run the melt_pool_3d example from malamute. When I run this, it runs for a single time step, and then stops until I stop the simulation. I am not sure what the problem is and any advice is appreciated.
@cticenhour

@mcp2001 did you mean the simulation terminated? What error did you see?
3D example is really expensive to run, and it requires significant memory because of LU solver. I suspect that your memory is not sufficient. If that is the case, could you run 2D example? We have been working to improve the code efficiency.

Hello and thanks for the reply,
The 2D example runs and I have run it for the full 1000 time steps with no problems. On the 3D example, there is not actually an error that happens, just after the Jacobian calculates the simulation stops computing and stays at that point for hours without progressing.
Could you check your memory usage? I suspect it uses swap memory or virtual memory, which makes it extremely slow.
Could you also run with Problem/error_on_jacobian_nonzero_reallocation=true?
Thank you very much, it was the memory that was the problem. What amount of memory would be recommended for this 3D simulation?

Hi @cticenhour @jiangwen84
I am trying out the MALAMUTE app. I could compile it fine. But the solve for the inputfile "examples/meltpool_2d/meltpool.i" did not converge. I cant figure out what went wrong. Can you guys help ?
Do you guys have any video of the expected solution ?
I have attached the output from MALAMUTE as shown below.
Thank you very much.

node.title: moving non-conforming meshes, and/or overset capabilities
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I was just wondering, as a possible newcomer and user of MOOSE with some C++/CFD experience, whether is possible to handle  moving non-conformal meshes (via interfaces, think of a moving propeller attached to a boat), and/or overset within the framework. I'm mostly interested in fluid flow simulations.
Regards,
Santiago

Hello
While we do have fluid flow capabilities, non-conformal meshes are only handled through custom interface treatments in MOOSE and we have not done much of that for fluid flow.
Were you looking for finite element or finite volume for fluid flow?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
In this particular case, my interest in non-conformal sliding meshes is mostly for fluid flows using FVM. I am also be interested on coupled solvers (as opposed to segregated) in FVM/FEM (for the study of polydisperse multiphase flows); this is one of the strongest reasons regarding my interest in MOOSE (SNES PETSc, under the hood but more abstract interface). I mean, there are some FVM libraries on the wild, but have a rather incipient treatment of coupled solvers and don't support PETSc.
Basically, I'd like to start with simulations using either sliding meshes (non-conformal, with non trivial topologies) or chimera (overset), if possible using INSE. I, generally, don't shy away from having to develop some code if needed but I'd like to get an idea of how much "time" it will require for me to get to the point I'm interested to be.
Many thanks for the attention,
Santiago

So we provide:

several FE & FV discretizations of the Navier Stokes equations for various flow regimes
a few turbulence models, with k-epsilon soon (coming months) to be merged for finite volume
examples of efficient preconditioning of flow & multiphysics equations through our interface to PETSc
limited multiphase capabilities for gas-liquid (in development) and liquid-solid
coupled solver is the default for now, we're adding a segregated solver in the coming months
Summary of flow capabilities: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/navier_stokes/index.html
the displaced mesh capabilities are shown best on our gallery
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/gallery.html

I'll let @lindsayad comment on a time estimate for dev of sliding meshes with FE flow

I would have to read about overset; I’m not familiar with it. We do have mortar methods which we use for sliding frictional contact in solid mechanics simulations. We’ve applied mortar to finite volume discretizations for gap heat transfer. Mortar has been our recent go-to for non conforming meshes. In the past we’ve also used node to face constraints (only in finite element contexts).
Looking briefly at overset I think a multi app approach with projections of fields between the different meshes would be the easiest approach with MOOSE

But that wouldn’t be in line with your principal interest of a fully coupled solve. At the libMesh implementation level we have one EquationSystems object per Mesh(Base). It’s an interesting question of how we might do this with two disconnected meshes in a single MeshBase object with projections between the two. @roystgnr have you ever had anyone interested in this type of thing? Thinking about this made me think of IBAMR but I think these are fundamentally different methods
Both mortar and IBM are surface couplings whereas you want to do volume couplings…

Hi @lindsayad,
Mortar couplings are a good start! For the first part of the study I have in mind "sliding meshes" are enough (noise propagation on a confined marine propeller). For this I don't need "multi-mesh equation coupling" or overset, since I'll go for classical INSE-LES and the topology of the disjoint meshes can be made non-overlapping.
... But, down the road, I'd like to study cavitation on said propeller (polydisperse multiphase models) which is more stable when the equations are coupled (Conservation of mass becomes critical between phases, hence a segregated approach tends to "break down" when the dispersed n-phase approaches zero). Notice here that level-set may be used for the resolution of the bubbles.
Finally I'd like to start adding more "topological features" (rudders, propellers) which are obviously "simpler" to mesh as disjointed, separate volume meshes.
At the risk of taking too much of your time, I'd like to expand a bit on the discussion we have now:

Mortar Methods: If I understood correctly you guys have a CHT case from which I might be able to use as "template" for a multi-region INSE solver.  Is that correct?
Level-Set: As I see in the examples, there is a PoC for level-set, however there are some suggestions on how to "generalize" it. is there any attempt now to build a two-phase (or multiphase) solver within DG or FVM?
Volume-coupling (overlapping meshes, Schwartz method, Overset) and Equation coupling: Is it necessary within MOOSE to also couple the "interpolation contribution" onto the "stiffness matrix", or can it be possible to handle the "inter-mesh" coupling explicitely? I understand there will be an interpolation and first-order-in-time error produced there but I suspect adding the interpolation stencils onto the matrix may be quite time consuming (one might need to search the nodes/centroids both in the domain as well as in the matrix) depending how the matrix is also stored in memory (I talk as a complete newbie with MOOSE, but as an avg user of petsc in FVM).

Anyway, I really thank you for taking the time to answer my questions (not very common in some FOSS CFD forums). I'll download the code and start trying it out so to get an idea on the workflow there.
Kind regards,
Santiago

Paul Bauman put some code in GRINS (another libMesh-based physics code) using overset grids for solid-fluid interactions.  There was no need to put two separate meshes in the same MeshBase there, though; the solid and fluid domains were just two overlapping subdomains of the same Mesh.  A few libMesh features (like feeding subdomain id sets to a PointLocator) are designed with that in mind, and IIRC Paul added some lookup caching on top of that (the PointLocatorTree is O(log N) and I guess switching to O(1) makes a difference when you're looking at every quadrature point...).  He also wrote a custom GhostingFunctor subclass to use as a coupling functor to handle the additional sparsity entries (and thereby incidentally handle the algebraic and geometric ghosting; man I'm proud of that API...).  I don't recall what he was doing for quadrature on the mismatching meshes, though.

We could ping Paul if we have any questions critical enough.  But GRINS is no longer officially maintained, and yet he still gives me a hand keeping it up to date when I run into any issues, and I still rely on it every now and then for added test coverage, so I don't want to abuse that privilege too hard.  His code is all LGPL, so we've got the goahead if there's anything like that ghosting functor that we want to bring into libMesh or MOOSE.

Mortar Methods: If I understood correctly you guys have a CHT case from which I might be able to use as "template" for a multi-region INSE solver.  Is that correct?


Yes, we have conjugate heat transfer, mechanical contact, etc. But only heat transfer demonstrated in a finite volume context, so that is probably the best template.


is there any attempt now to build a two-phase (or multiphase) solver within DG or FVM?


We have two-phase flow in a 7 equation model using rDG(P0P1) (so finite volume) in the relap-7 application, but we'd like to get something in our MOOSE modules. You can see #22637 for discussion on the topic. In short, our team at Idaho National Laboratory is not currently doing anything, but we'd love to see movement on the topic.

3. olume-coupling (overlapping meshes, Schwartz method, Overset) and Equation coupling

Based on @roystgnr's response, I think we could definitely so something here

node.title: In PP or VPP, display matrix results with changeable size

node.bodyText:
Hello
VPP aren’t meant to deal with vectors of vectors.
you ll either want to work on a Reporter, which is a more general but more complex object than a VPP
or simply define multiple VPPs for each vector within the vector of vectors
Guillaume

Thank you very much.
That's precisely what I've been stuck on.  If I define three independent vectors instead of a vector of vectors. I'm still not sure what 'AuxVariables,' 'AuxKernels,' and 'VPP (or Reporter)' might be used to read all dates from a vector with varying sizes.
For instance, if there is just a defined vector, supply a vector of values in each iteration, as seen below.
Would you please kindly tell me which 'AuxVariables,' 'AuxKernels,' and 'VPP' are capable of aggregating and displaying all values for each iteration?
[Materials]
  [./d]
  .
  .
  .
  a1_calc = 'a1_calc'
  [../]
[ ]
Results:
t= 1: a1_calc = {1, 2, 3, 4}
t= 2: a1_calc = {6, 14, 3, 4, 22, 13, 18}
t= 3: a1_calc = {56, 14, 3, 4, 72, 13, 48, 16, 0, 0, 12, 13}
t= n: a1_calc = {a_1, ...a_m}

'AuxVariables,' are meant for data sized with the number of elements/nodes in the mesh. So this is not what you want if i understand correctly.
A VPP should be able to do this.
(and now that I've taken a closer look, multiple vectors are supported by VPPs! As long as the number of vectors is known at construction as far as I can tell)
Some examples of dynamically sized vector postprocessors are:

the samples, derived from SamplerBase. The size is directed by the derived class, the number of nodes for the NodalValueSampler for example
the eigenvalues VPP

A lot of the other VPPs have their vectors sized on initialization. It would not be challenging to size on execute instead.

node.title: [Mesh] Meshing a small cubic within a big cubic
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I want to use MOOSE Mesh blocks to build a small cubic (i.e., 2m2m2m) within a big cubic (i.e., 1km1km1km).
One solution may be to build a quite refined mesh (i.e., 0.25m0.25m0.25m) for the whole big cubic (i.e., 1km1km1km) and then use SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator to select the small cubic. But it needs many elements for the out parts of the small cubic. I don't want this.
In addition, I try to build and refine the two cubics by 'FileMeshGenerator' and then using 'StitchedMeshGenerator' to merge them together, but it produces repeated meshing in their intersection parts.
Could you please give me some suggestions on this? Thanks a lot.
J

Hello
the solution here is likely to use mesh refinement.
First : generate the uniform grid for the whole domain. It should be as coarse as you want the large coarse part to be. CartesianMG or rectilinearMG should both be able to do it
second: use the subdomain bounding box to create a different subdomain for the fine part. You could skip that part if you use the subdomain_ids argument of the rectilinearMG
Then use the BlockRefineGenerator to refine only the fine part a few levels. You want to get to the fineness required there
finally, if the fine part was “too big” in step 2, you can redefine it again using another subsomainBoundingBox generator
Guillaume

Hello
the solution here is likely to use mesh refinement.
First : generate the uniform grid for the whole domain. It should be as coarse as you want the large coarse part to be. CartesianMG or rectilinearMG should both be able to do it
second: use the subdomain bounding box to create a different subdomain for the fine part. You could skip that part if you use the subdomain_ids argument of the rectilinearMG
Then use the BlockRefineGenerator to refine only the fine part a few levels. You want to get to the fineness required there
finally, if the fine part was “too big” in step 2, you can redefine it again using another subsomainBoundingBox generator
Guillaume

Thanks a lot. I will try this way.

node.title: Use the code autocomplete in VS Code
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to use the code autocomplete in VS Code. I have attempted to use the MOOSE Language Support extension, but it keeps displaying the error message "No MOOSE application executable found". Where should I provide the path for the MOOSE application? I have noticed in the extension settings that I can provide a HIT format style file, but I am not sure what HIT is and how to provide it. Will providing this file make the extension work? My VS Code is running on Windows and connected to WSL. I am not very familiar with VS Code. Can someone please help me?

Hello
if you are working in the repository of the application, like in the tests or examples folder for example, it should find it automatically
if not then you should create a symlink to the executable in your local working folder
Guillaume
This worked. Thank you very much.

    [../]
    [./plas]
      type = IsotropicPlasticityStressUpdate
      hardening_constant = 0.5
      yield_stress =300
    [../]

When I use block [stress] , another block [radial_return_stress]  can't be used. So I had to go into hiding.
Can I use together?
Lily

Hello
No you cannot define multiple stress models on the same blocks (subdomains), unless you use either the "suffix" parameter to disambiguate them.
Fyi:

So I had to go into hiding.

You had to comment it out. Going into hiding means something else.

We want to add creep, plastic deformation, elastic deformation and thermal expansion into the equation. Is there any similar code available？
Lily

I think the ComputeMultipleInelasticStress is the way to go, which you are already using.
Others may pitch in for alternatives

Lily

Did I miss any necessary syntax? Btw, if I want to add my own closures, should I create a new material class like ADWallFrictionChurchillMaterial and ADWallHeatTransferCoefficient3EqnDittusBoelterMaterial?
Ethan

Hi Ethan,
This is because you have 2 heat transfers attached to your flow channel, so you need to define the heat transfer coefficient material for each heat transfer (Hw:1 and Hw:2).  By default, the name of the material created by ADWallHeatTransferCoefficeint3EqnDittusBoelterMaterial  is Hw. You can change it by adding the parameter Hw to your block and specify Hw:1 or Hw:2, and also adjust the T_wall parameter to T_wall:1 and T_wall:2. Note that you will also need to create the material from the aux variable for these 2 wall temperatures. See below:
[Hw1_mat]
   type = ADWallHeatTransferCoefficient3EqnDittusBoelterMaterial
   D_h = D_h
   rho = rho
   vel = vel
   T = T
   T_wall = T_wall:1
   cp = cp
   mu = mu
   k = k
  block = ${list_of_blocks_with_2_HT}
 []
 [Hw2_mat]
   type = ADWallHeatTransferCoefficient3EqnDittusBoelterMaterial
   D_h = D_h
   rho = rho
   vel = vel
   T = T
   T_wall = T_wall:2
   cp = cp
   mu = mu
   k = k
  block = ${list_of_blocks_with_2_HT}
 []

[T_wall1_mat]
 type = ADCoupledVariableValueMaterial
 prop_name = T_wall:1
 coupled_variable = T_wall:1
 block = ${list_of_blocks_with_2_HT}
[]

[T_wall2_mat]
 type = ADCoupledVariableValueMaterial
 prop_name = T_wall:2
 coupled_variable = T_wall:2
 block = ${list_of_blocks_with_2_HT}
[]
Thank you!

node.title: ADGenericFunctorMaterials not recognized by the diffusion kernel
node.bodyText:
I have a diffusivity coefficient (DO18int and DO16int) that depends on the variable itself (O16int and O18int) both spatially and temporally. I have found that the ADGenericFunctorMaterials achieves this but I am unable to get it working. The console outputs the error:
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".

Material property 'DO16int', requested by 'diff_O16int' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'DO18int', requested by 'diff_O18int' is not defined on block 0
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here is what my input file looks like pertaining to the Variables, Materials and Kernels block.

[Variables]
  [O16int]
    initial_condition = 0.992
  []
  [O18int]
    initial_condition = 0.002
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [Y16]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = Y16
    coupled_variables = 'O16int O18int'
    expression = 'O16int/(O16int+O18int)'
  []
  [Y18]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = Y18
    coupled_variables = 'O16int O18int'
    expression = 'O18int/(O16int+O18int)'
  []
  [DO16int]
    type = ADGenericFunctorMaterial
    prop_names = 'DO16int'
    prop_values = 'Y16*5'
  []
  [DO18int]
    type = ADGenericFunctorMaterial
    prop_names = 'DO18int'
    prop_values = 'Y18*5'
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff_O16int]
    type = ADMatDiffusion
    diffusivity = DO16int
    variable = O16int
  []
  [dO16intdt]
    type = ADTimeDerivative
    variable = O16int
  []
  [diff_O18int]
    type = ADMatDiffusion
    diffusivity = DO18int
    variable = O18int
  []
  [dO18intdt]
    type = ADTimeDerivative
    variable = O18int
  []
[]

Hello
functor materials are different from regular materials, and are not compatible with ADMatDiffusion
you want to use a Parsed Material not a functor material here
Guillaume
